subject: RE: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: Your definiton of Better Software lacks any sort of standards to make a quantitative analysis. How fast? How much value? What is business value? Unless your
messageBody:
Your definiton of Better Software lacks any sort of standards to make a
quantitative analysis.
How fast? How much value? What is business value? Unless your definition
contains definable
quantities then your definition is vague and ambiguous. Who determines the
business value?
Do you go out and get ROI numbers on the projects you do for your customers?
Or is business
value a feel good thing that you and your customer agree on at the end of
the project?

Thank you

Michael Holly

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Friday, August 22, 2003 9:49 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals
urgently)


Michael Holly wrote:

> Listers please excuse the off topic nature.

Don't worry about it.

> Let me reply with some examples from the manufaturing industry.

Please do not compare software to manufacturing. They are not similar.
Instead, compare building software to product design and try again.
<snip />

> Now correct me if I am wrong (I'm sure you will) but better software
> development
> is about
>
> definable, documentable interfaces,
> modularization,
> testing ... repeatable testing,
> frameworks,
> patterns,
> components,
> automated documentation
> etc.

No. Better software is about delivering business value faster. The
things you list help us get there, but that list changes over time. They
are just today's tools.

> All of these concepts drive toward 'uniform' results. Even this
newsgroup's
> purpose
> is about promotion of software that allows repeatable testing. Better
> software development
> is completely about bringing 'uniformity' to the process.

I don't like this, but I can't articulate an alternative. I'm working on it.

> If you have a definition of 'better software' then please supply it

Above. Software is better if it brings more value to my customer faster.
More value in the same time or same value faster would each also be better.

> This
> definition
> has to exist, otherwise, you have no standard to compare your latest
project
> to validate
> that it is better. The feedback you are getting from this comparison will
> make *gasp* your
> process better!

XP is not about defining a process; it is about building up a toolkit
and learning how the tools work and when to use them. Judgment remains
the key ingredient and a defined process *encourages* me to *ignore* my
own judgment.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
